ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: basic understanding of macroeconomics and small ties to public policy
A good intro to macroeconomics and market understanding.
Good macroeconomic baseline, interesting facts and frameworks.

I really learned a ton of content in this course! While studying for the final exam, I realized just how much material we got through in the semester. I developed my critical/analytical skills, math skills, graphing skills, etc. This course has provided me with the skills to read articles in The Economist, the WSJ, the Financial Times, etc. Now I actually understand the terms so I can understand what they're talking about!!
Gained economic knowledge more applicable to the real world than micro.
I learned about macroeconomic models such as the Slow Model and the IS-MP model. We were given tools that allowed us to evaluate current economic trends in the world.
A fundamental understanding of macro economics.
I acquired greater knowledge about the US system as an international student which allowed me to gain a broader perspective of the functioning of different economies around the world

After micro last semester, I was excited to take a course with a different perspective on economics. I enjoyed learning about the economy more broadly, and found the class to be far less numbers based than 115.
Learned how to look at economics with a larger scope. Combination of math and economic concepts.

Through this course, I gained a solid foundation in Macroeconomics that allowed me to become more aware of how the economy operates. This course gives a very well-rounded yet nuanced view of economics, so I was able to learn both foundational knowledge and its applications. For example, we started the course by learning how to construct models of GDP, but by the end of the course, we learned how to interpret and apply those models to explain the behavior of specific economies.
This class was a great introduction to macroeconomics. It is understandably broad and encompasses very well what the subject includes should a student choose to pursue further interest.
An introduction to macroeconomics at a level deeper than AP Macroeconomics.
The basics of macroeconomics.
greater insight into the introductory topics of microeconomics

I gained an understanding of the determinants of economic growth, how to calculate GDP, and short and long-run models of economic development. I also better understand the financial system, determinants of social mobility and social/income inequality, monetary and fiscal policy, and the role of the Federal Reserve and the federal government in stabilizing the economy.
Great class
Insight into long run and short run growth of economies, introduction to 2008 financial crises, government debt, monetary policy, and the financial sector.
I felt like I learned the basics of macroeconomics from inflation to world trade to asset pricing to the many models we learned in class.
I learned more about the general economy and how overall businesses operate, instead of specific firms.

This course developed my ability to use quantitative methods (graphs and equations) to describe macroeconomic trends, taught me about a number of key studies in the field of macroeconomics, and developed my ability to use independent reasoning to explain the reasons behind macroeconomic concepts.

I imbued my knowledge on topics about the worlds macroeconomy managed to handle macroeconomic tools. Some of the topics explored were very important and applicable todays world in many different current events. Overall, I feel the class was a very good introduction to Macroeconomics.
Basic macroeconomics concepts, understanding of basic macroeconomics models (IS-MP, International Trade, Unemployment, Labor Markets, etc.).
Basic understanding of macroeconomics

This course was instrumental in enhancing my knowledge and skills in macroeconomics. It offered an accessible and well-structured approach to a range of complex topics. Key areas such as GDP analysis, international trade, business cycles, and monetary policy were covered in depth. Additionally, the course effectively addressed crucial issues like economic inequality. One of the strengths of this course was how it linked theoretical concepts to current economic discussions and topics. This real-world relevance not only aided in understanding but also increased the practical utility of the knowledge gained. The balance between theoretical frameworks and their practical applications was particularly appreciated.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: overall a pretty good course, there wasnt much wrong with it other than the fact sometimes we talked in circles but thats true for every econ course
I liked the worksheets/pset pairs. Good resources. Prof Peters is a great lecturer and the course is super well structured. Prof Hawkins was great too!! No complaints!

This course was organized VERY well. We had access to lecture slides, previous exams, section slides, lecture summaries, and literally anything else we could've needed! All of the logistical information was easily accessible, all deadlines were made extremely clear. I was never confused about the expectations in this course. The Psets and workshets were challenging, but manageable and helpful for my understanding of the content. There isn't much that I'd do to improve the course!
It's a class where you know exactly what it will look like.
I liked the worksheets, they were a good learning tool.

Strengths: it was well organized and the lectures were posted online in a timely manner. Weaknesses: it's not a very interactive course, which is to be expected, as it's a large lecture (although Prof. Peters tried to encouraged participation in the lecture).
The strengths was the office hours. The weakness was the pace of the lectures.

I think a strength of this course is how a lot of the concepts can be reinforced by math
A weakness is how specific certain questions on the exam are regarding things such as the exact savings rate of the US or the exact percentage of labor share of income
Very well organized and well-taught. So many materials and resources available for you all the time.
I thought this course was taught very well. The slides were clear. I wish we had done a little more practice with the concepts in class, instead of just in section and on the PSets.
I think that there are a lot of conversations in class when it should be more lecture style.

A strength of the course is the various supplementary materials that are concise and easily accessible. The lecture slides, textbook, and TF support were monumental in making the course more engaging.
I greatly appreciated the worksheets, they were a great, risk-free way of ensuring understanding of course content.
One of the strengths was that the course was very well organized.
I thought it was really good and I don't really have many suggestions for improvement.

Strengths: This course comprehensively covers topics that I think everyone should have some baseline amount of knowledge around, even if you're not an economics major. I also think that this course is pretty applicable and relevant to the real world in ways that other introductory classes may not be. For instance, in almost every lecture, our professor connected what we were learning back to some historical or contemporary relevance. Sections covered confusing points from lecture and were largely guided by what students felt needed to be covered, which was helpful. The Ed Discussion thread also was immensely helpful for quick questions and we received responses very shortly after posting questions.

Weakness: I felt as though the styles of our exams, particularly the final, were more a test of our test-taking skills as opposed to our knowledge of macroeconomics. While tests should be a combination of both, a lot of questions felt as though they were skewed toward the former. Something that I struggled with was that a lot of lectures were conducted in a way that assumed everyone had the same base-level fluency and understanding of economics concepts that not everyone has. For instance, the lecture on the financial crisis was particularly hard to grasp.
Tough exams!

Really well delivered lectures, organized, very quick turnaround for grades, lots of opportunities to get help (great office hours, quick responses on Ed Discussion). 

No weaknesses.

I found it difficult to be fully present and giving my full attention to the lecture for the whole 75 minutes. However, the lecture itself was fantastic and I also really enjoyed the discussion section as well.
Good sections
The course was very well organized.

The course's lectures were very engaging and integrated current/recent events in order to allow us to connect theoretical concepts to real-life trends. The course also had excellent TAs and support for exams/problem sets, including review materials, worksheet assignments, and review sessions.

The weaknesses were definitely the exams. All exams were very hard, and, most importantly, very vague and long. In my opinion, they were very hard to complete within the given time and we needed extra time for all of them. Also, some of the questions were very ambiguous. The correct answer was not straightforward. In both exams and problem sets, the true-false questions were not clear at all, some were not even covered in class, and all answers seemed plausible. In general, they were very vague, which means that all answers and explanations seemed correct. This is confirmed by the fact that at the solutions of exams and problem sets, the course team accepted multiple answers as correct. This means that in some cases people who had answered true and people who had answered false in a true false question, received the same amount of credit, which means that the question was not covered in class, not clear and vague enough to just give credit to everybody.

I also think that doing the aggregate demand/aggregate supply model would be more effective and useful than the I S/MP Phillips model. Not seeing the aggregate demand aggregate supply model in an introductory macro class confused me a bit.

BUT, I think the strengths of this class outweigh the weaknesses. The biggest strength was definitely organisation and help from the course staff, course director, and the TAs was very helpful in answering all the questions, and the most helpful resource was the Ed discussion forum. Everybody was very helpful in both administrative and practical questions, and I quite appreciated that, I think this greatly facilitated my learning and navigating through this class.

Overall, I think the course is quite strong and structured well. The workload was reasonable and we still managed to cover a lot of material. There was real world knowledge gained over the course as well, in addition to theory.

Strengths: Professor Peters is a fantastic lecturer and a great mentor; he always makes himself available to students and genuinely cares about the growth and progress of his students. I also felt very well supported by the peer tutors and TAs, and, overall, I felt that the course was designed well to maximize learning efficacy and help students succeed. No significant weaknesses.

The strengths of this course were that the workload and presentations were regimented. However, there were not many opportunities to engage with the professor in order to grasp the course material to a greater degree.
Very clear information, but exams were intended to trick students who knew the information well
The course materials and teaching methods facilitated manageable learning, even with complex subjects. This approach fostered a deeper understanding and engagement with the subject matter.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes! but only with michael peters bc hes delightful and so passionate about his work
Yes.
Yes, its interesting and I think this information is useful for anyone - not just economics majors. Better than macro, too.

Yes!! I would 100% recommend this course to another student, even if they're not planning on majoring in economics/anything related. This course is helpful for understanding the world and will allow you to develop a basic literacy in important economic/financial terms.
Recommend? Probably not. But again, most people don't take this class because they want to, it's a prerequisite for something else - and there's nothing wrong with that.

Michael Peters is an incredible young professor, miles better than any old curmudgeon that you could end up with. His enthusiasm for the course material is infectious, and he makes a sincere effort at audience engagement during the lectures. The worksheets and psets are not impossible, and genuinely help facilitate learning. With Peters as professor, this class becomes one of those in which the grade you earn in the class reflects the effort you put into it.
Not for enjoyment but if they are econ majors
Yes, especially if they are an econ major. Even for non-con majors, it gives you a nice overview of economic trends worldwide.
Yes, very helpful.
Yes because it helps you develop a basic foundation for macroeconomic activity
Yes. It is a requirement if you are an ECON major but I would recommend taking it even if you are not if you want to learn basic macroeconomics that will be relevant in real life as well.
I would. It is a good intro economics course.
Yes, it is a great introduction into the economics major.

I would recommend this course to another student because it provides foundational knowledge that is essential not only to college but everyday life. Even if someone didn't plan on pursuing a degree in economics, this knowledge is still very applicable to their lives.
I would. It is an introductory class and is great at what it is supposed to do.
No, I wouldn't recommend taking it just for fun. I think that you should only take this course if it's a requirement.
Yes: even if you're not majoring in economics or an adjacent subject, this is a fantastic introduction to an important topic.

I would recommend this course to another student because I believe it teaches topics that are relevant to everyone, not just economics majors. No matter the field you are going in, but especially if it concerns politics, international relations, or economics obviously, it's helpful to understand how economic policy is conducted, how trade works, and how the financial system works.
Yes, great for macroeconomic theory
Yes, a great introduction to important economic principles.
Yes, as a introductory class to a massive part of economics, this class is very important just to get an understanding on how macroeconomist works and what it contains.
Yes, it is a decent introductory course.

I would recommend this course to another student interested in learning more about macroeconomics, even if they are not an economics (or related) major. The course provides an understanding of topics that can be applied easily in the real world, and to a variety of disciplines.
I would, as I said it served as an excellent introduction to macro economics. I would have to say this is a very challenging and quite a difficult class although it is interesting.
Yep, macroecon is something I think everyone should take just to be able to process and understand key parts of our world.

With Professor Peters, I would very much recommend this course. I took this course off-cycle, and I was very pleased with the smaller lecture size and more interactive lecturing style. Overall, I highly recommend this course for any prospective Economics majors or students who wish to gain a better understanding of macroeconomics for their everyday life.
If you are an Econ major
Yes! Especially for non-majors who want a good introduction into macroeconomics
